Post Description:
We officially started the Sea-Air Vaccination Exercise for our frontliners working at our borders on 18 Jan 2021. 

The attached graph shows the progress made in the maritime sector. 

The top horizontal line shows the number of frontline workers eligible - 18k. 

The first line bordering the blue area shows the number that got their first dose over the last 1.5 months. The number now stands at 17.6k, or 98% of eligible frontline maritime personnel. 

The second line bordering the green area shows the number who have received the second dose of the COVID-19 vaccine. 16.7k have, and in the coming days, almost all would have. 

This means that substantially all frontline maritime workers will be vaccinated, and this is a major step in securing our borders and minimising import cases infiltrating our community, and strengthening international confidence in our maritime hub. 

I thank the various stakeholders - @maritime_sg, EDB, EnterpriseSG, SMOU, SOS, SSA, ASMI, @moh_singapore, Fullerton Health, maritime companies, and also workers and their families, for their tremendous support. 

#MaritimeSGSteadyLah
#MaritimeSG
Comments: ‚ù§Ô∏è‚ù§Ô∏è‚ù§Ô∏è Well done! Thank you for protecting our frontline specialists.

Post Description:
My fellow Sembawang GRC MPs spoke in Parliament during the Budget Debate over the last two days.

Dr Lim Wee Kiak called for the rebate package for taxi and private hire drivers to be brought forward, which Government has followed up on.

Ms Mariam explained why when evaluating Singapore√¢‚Ç¨‚Ñ¢s carbon emission, we need to take into account of the fact that Singapore is a city state which provides aviation, maritime and chemical processing services to the rest of the world.

Ms Poh Li San spoke about how Singapore, despite its limitations, has set a good international example on sustainability and conservation.

Mr Vikram Nair had useful suggestions on how to encourage more people to receive Covid-19 vaccinations.

Thank you to the voices of Sembawang MPs! #MakeSembawangSpecial
Comments: Very nice of you to be profiling your team of MPs. Good leadership! üòä

Post Description:
Mr Tham, 72, was one of the first taxi drivers to get vaccinated today. 

More than 50,000 active taxi and private hire car drivers will receive an SMS this week to book their vaccination slot. 

Amongst the more than 12,000 taxi and PHC drivers who went for voluntary swab test last September, none tested positive. This is partly due to all the safe measures that have been put in place. 

Notwithstanding, vaccination is an important added protection for our drivers, their families and commuters. 

Thank you to the drivers for stepping forward and setting aside time to get your vaccinations.

Stay well and drive safe!
Comments: A little jab will surely make cabbies drive a longer way.

Post Description: I was at the launch of our Sea-Air Vaccination Exercise yesterday, during which I delivered a 10 min speech to explain why it is so important for our aviation and maritime workers to get vaccinated. I have condensed the speech and recorded a 2.5 min version.  No need to play at x2, because I already spoke very fast! Hope this explains.
Comments: Singapore - because of smart policies and high discipline ! - has the luxury that we don‚Äôt have the Virus here and that people don‚Äôt die ! Therefore in Singapore it is possible that front line workers like in aviation and maritime can get vaccinated first! That is a hard earned privilege for the whole country to focus now on economic recovery! Most other (often Western) countries don‚Äôt have this choice ! Well done Singapore ! üá∏üá¨

Post Description:
Today, we start the Sea-Air #Vaccination Exercise, to vaccinate 37,000 frontliners of the #aviation and #maritime industry. 

They are our airplane and port pilots, cabin crew, cargo handlers, transit lounge workers, local seafarers, ship and plane repair technicians etc. 

Some 13,000 of them have registered to be vaccinated this week, and hopefully more will do so in the coming weeks as we step up the capacity of the two vaccination centres at @changiairport T4 and Raffles City to 8,000 a day. 

We aim to substantially complete the exercise within two months. 

These 37,000 workers come into contact with people and cargo from outside #Singapore. When vaccinated, they will not just protect themselves and their families, but they would have taken a big step to secure the borders of Singapore and keep us safe from COVID-19.

#OneAviation #MaritimeSG
Comments: Minister Ong, what about our MRT customer service guys that are always on rhe Station platforms and bus captains. When will they be vaccinated.

Post Description:
We start vaccination for the #aviation and #maritime sectors this afternoon, at two centres: @changiairport T4 for air crew and frontline airport workers, and Raffles City Convention Centre for marine pilots, crew and frontline workers who have to go onboard ships.

This week will be an operational warm-up, where we will vaccinate small groups, to prepare for full scale operations next week. 

I will be at T4 with the CEOs of key aviation companies next Monday to explain the significance of this exercise.
Comments: Big thanks for the effort!

Post Description:
A historic cold chain moment on the night of Winter Solstice Festival (√•‚Ä†¬¨√®‚Ä°¬≥). The first vaccine shipment has finally arrived, safely and smoothly.

It reached our tarmac from Brussels this evening, on a @singaporeair cargo plane. From flight to delivery, a lot of preparation has gone into making this as smooth as possible, including a trial flight by #SIA.

Changi air hub ecosystem has been working out the processes for months, with a specially set up Taskforce. One of the challenges they identified was to ensure sufficient supply of dry ice. So #SATS is now producing 4 tonnes of dry ice per day, on its own facility!

The real work starts now.
Comments: Big appreciation to all involved!

Changi air hub ecosystem has been working out the processes for months, with a specially set up Taskforce. One of the challenges they identified was to ensure sufficient supply of dry ice. So #SATS is now producing 4 tonnes of dry ice per day, on its own facility!

The real work starts now.
Comments: Really hope all normal cool chain movements daily can be as smooth as today. Perishables take half a day to clear on normal days. Sats cargo need to improve their daily operations rather than flog the limelight about a one time shipment.

Post Description:
The world is gearing up to receive millions of vaccine doses, #Singapore stands ready to transport and distribute COVID-19 vaccines when it reaches our shores.

With a combined cool chain handling capacity of 375,000 tonnes - more than 5 times the expected volume of vaccines coming into our region - our air cargo ecosystem is ready to play a key role in this international distribution process.

From plane to delivery, here√¢‚Ç¨‚Ñ¢s how one of our key players, #SATS, does it.
Comments: When we'll we ne getting the vaccine

Post Description:
Today, I dropped by the monthly job fair at Kampung Admiralty with @pohlisan. The job fair is supported by NTUC e2i.

Out of more than 2,700 immediate job vacancies by 80 employers at the fair, 2,300 jobs are located in and around Sembawang GRC. Our volunteers have been calling on local enterprises to gather these job vacancies. 

Job Stations at the fair, available in the four official languages, can also help residents by highlighting jobs within the 5km radius. And companies present at the fair will interview interested applicants on the spot. 

This has been a difficult period for residents whose jobs are affected by COVID-19. I hope the job fair will help.

#MakeSembawangSpecial @ilovee2i
Comments: If is not good is aready the best done we can ask for more

Post Description:
This is the √¢‚Ç¨≈ìhealth certificate√¢‚Ç¨¬ù that may come in handy when you travel next time.

COVID-19 test results, and soon, your vaccination status, may become very relevant information at the check-in and immigration counters for cross border travel. But they will need to be easily verifiable.

Airlines are foreseeing this. So @singaporeair is working with International Air Transport Association (#IATA), and #Affinidi, a local technology company founded by @temasekseen, to start a trial on digital verification for COVID-19 tests and soon, vaccinations.

Accredited labs will issue a health certificate - a QR code on mobile or printed on paper - to passengers, to be scanned and verified easily and securely by airlines and immigration officers using an app.

Hopefully, with the support of IATA, various airlines and authorities around the world, this can become the norm, and replace the yellow book.

I applaud the industry√¢‚Ç¨‚Ñ¢s initiative. @motsingapore and #CAAS will support this as much as we can, to make this a regional or international practice. We are #OneAviation team. 

Photo credit: Affinidi
[The verifier app developed by Affinidi (foreground) lets airline staff and ICA officials easily scan QR codes to verify COVID-19 test results. The QR code in the background is stored on a separate app developed by International SOS.]
Comments: This is really soooo amazing. Feeling very blessed that we're so organised and systematic in the way we do things. Kudos to the people who did all the planning with so much thought and foresight.

Post Description:
Phase 3 announced, vaccines in transit. Steps will also be taken, to allow limited, safe, face-to-face international business meetings.

Zoom cannot replace some face-to-face business meetings, e.g. signing agreements, or discussing with key teams, getting to know key partners in person.

Connect@Changi, will provide the first of its kind facility to enable such meetings to be carried out safely.

This is a national resilience project, led by @temasekseen, @surbanajurong, @changiairport, Ascott and SingEx.

This video explains how it is done.
Comments: Thank you sir for the efforts üí™üëç
